Listen to the following speaker talking about the electronic ticket.

Passengers may want to have their tickets in hand before catching their planes, but the airline companies are doing everything they can to bring forward cost-saving electronic ticketâ€”no paper needed, just a ticket number and a photo ID card. Anyone who buys a Northwest e-ticket through the airline's computer service by June 16 will get an award. Next time you fly, you can buy another ticket for a friend for $99, going anywhere in the US or Canada through Dec. 12, 2016 along with the lowest ticket prices.

Some airlines offer frequent passenger extra miles for the electronic ticket. And there is rising punishment for paper lovers. Last week, America, Northwest, United, and US Airways have raised the cost for lost-ticket replacement to $70 from either $60 or $50. The airlines insist that the increase in price is not meant to push travellers toward e-tickets but only cover the increasing cost of replacing and tracking a missing ticket.
